channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Poland Suggests Russian-Made Missile Killed 2 Inside Its Borders
item.description: The explosion in a Polish village across the border from Ukraine occurred as Russia bombarded Ukrainian cities with about 100 missiles.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A residential neighborhood in Kyiv, Ukraine, where a building was struck by debris from a Russian missile shot down by Ukrainian air-defense systems on Tuesday.

item.title: At G20 Summit, Xi and Biden Offer Rival Visions for Solving Global Issues
item.description: China and the United States showed how global summits are an arena for great powers to compete, with implications for the war in Ukraine and Asia’s future.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Sui-Lee Wee and Katie Rogers
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: President Biden and China’s leader, Xi Jinping, in Bali on Tuesday.

item.title: As U.K. Braces for Painful Budget Cuts, the Mood Is Gloomy
item.description: Swindon, west of London, has reinvented itself several times, always a rung lower on the economic ladder. Now it awaits another step down.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: An empty Debenhams department store looming over Swindon’s main shopping district. The store closed in 2020 during a pandemic lockdown.

item.title: Iran Cracks Down as Protests Show No Sign of Easing
item.description: Security forces fired on a crowd at a metro station on Tuesday, setting off a panicked rush of commuters, video showed.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: via Reuters; via AFP — Getty; via AFP — Getty
item.media:description: Images from social media videos from Iran posted on Tuesday that purported to show protesters at Azad University in Khomeyni Shahr, Iran, left; at a mall in Isfahan, Iran, center; and blocking traffic in Tehran.

item.title: Iran Unleashes Its Wrath on Its Children for Joining Protests
item.description: Hundreds of minors have been detained for joining the demonstrations, and many others have died in the crackdown, according to Iranian lawyers and rights activists.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: In Brazil, Lula Beat Bolsonaro. Now Comes the Hard Part.
item.description: Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva had one of Latin America’s best presidencies ever in the century’s first decade. His second try looks far more difficult.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and André Spigariol
item.media:credit: Maria Magdalena Arrellaga for The New York Times
item.media:description: Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva before the final presidential debate ahead of the runoff election last month in Rio de Janeiro.

item.title: Alaa Abd El Fattah Ends Hunger Strike in Egypt, Family Says
item.description: During the U.N. climate conference in Egypt, world leaders pressed the Egyptian president to release Alaa Abd El Fattah, who has been on a hunger strike for more than seven months.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Alaa Abd El Fattah in court in 2015. His family said he has asked his mother to bring food when she visits him in prison on Thursday, his birthday.

item.title: Palestinian Assailant Kills 3 Israelis in West Bank
item.description: The attack began in a settlement industrial zone and continued along a highway, and took place on the day that Israel is to swear in a new Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Israeli security officers at the site of the attack near the settlement of Ariel, in the West Bank, on Tuesday.

item.title: In Poland, a Warm Welcome for Ukrainian Refugees Wobbles
item.description: Poland took in millions of people fleeing the war in Ukraine. But a vocal minority is trying to stoke tensions as Russian attacks threaten to prompt a new surge.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ruslana Medvedeva, left, and her daughter and mother, far right, and the Krykota family, center, are Ukrainian refugees who share a room at the Lodz Baptist Church.

item.title: New Measure of Climate’s Toll: Disasters Are Now Common Across US
item.description: A new report found that 90 percent of all counties nationwide have suffered a major disaster since 2011.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:description: Members of the fire department in Jackson, Ky., patrolling the downtown after torrential rains brought devastating floods this summer.

item.title: Divided Government
item.description: A split Congress could lead to government shutdowns and economic turmoil.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Capitol on Monday.

item.title: A Clash at Climate Talks: Should Nations Keep the 1.5-Degree Goal?
item.description: The mantra has been: Limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius or risk climate catastrophe. But at COP27, there are hints of backsliding.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer, David Gelles and Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Protesters at the United Nations climate summit in Sharm el Sheikh, Egypt, on Saturday.

item.title: G20 Summit Ends With Sanctions on Russia Still Dividing Some Countries
item.description: The meeting did not result in the customary joint communiqué, and the “leaders’ declaration” issued instead noted “different assessments” of the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: As the Group of 20 summit in Bali drew to a close on Wednesday, President Joko Widodo of Indonesia, right, handed a gavel to Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India.

item.title: Lockdowns Set Off Rare Protest in Guangzhou in China
item.description: Weary migrants thronged a street in the manufacturing hub of Guangzhou to protest food shortages and lengthy stay-at-home orders under China’s strict “zero-Covid” policy.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che and John Liu
item.media:description: People protesting in Guangzhou, China, in November, in this still image obtained from a video.

item.title: Amid Crises, Biden Offers the World a Choice: My Way, or Trump’s
item.description: The president put his coalition-building approach on display on a trip through Asia, where he sought to ease tensions with China.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley and Katie Rogers
item.media:description: President Biden before speaking to reporters after a meeting of G7 and NATO leaders in Bali, Indonesia, on Wednesday.

item.title: How Britain’s Crackdown on Gangs Disproportionately Targets Young Black Men
item.description: A murder-conspiracy case in northwestern England tells the story of Britain’s crackdown on gangs, which disproportionately targets young Black men.
item.dc:creator: Selam Gebrekidan
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ademola Adedeji in a park in Bolton, England, in April. Mr. Adedeji’s life changed on Nov. 5, 2020, when he got word that his childhood friend, John Soyoye, had been stabbed.

item.title: Jeremy Hunt Will Be the UK’s Bearer of Bad News
item.description: Jeremy Hunt, the chancellor of the Exchequer, is known for his competence and sober demeanor, which he will most likely need as he outlines tax increases and public spending cuts.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Tejas Sandhu/SOPA Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Jeremy Hunt in London in July.

item.title: NATO envoys gather as the explosion in Poland alarms the alliance.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña and Shashank Bengali
item.media:description: Polish government officials at the country’s National Security Bureau headquarters in Warsaw on Tuesday.

item.title: How Countries Are Responding to the Explosion in Poland
item.description: Poland said a Russian-made missile was involved. Russia has denied involvement.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Polish police officers patrolled the village of Przewodow, about four miles from the Ukrainian border, after Tuesday’s explosion.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: A missile that killed two people in Poland does not appear to have come from Russia, according to President Biden.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: How a US Teacher Evaded Russian Troops in Kherson for 8 Months
item.description: Timothy Morales, a teacher, was trapped in the southern Ukrainian city during the occupation. To evade Russian troops, he rarely ventured out, switched apartments and pretended to be Irish.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Timothy Morales, 56, an American teacher, managed to send his 10-year-old daughter to safety, but was trapped in occupied Kherson, Ukraine, during Russia’s occupation.

item.title: Biden Says Missile That Killed 2 in Poland Was Probably Not Fired From Russia
item.description: It was unclear from the president’s remarks whether he meant the missile was not likely to have been fired from inside Russia, or by Russian forces in Ukraine or elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: President Biden in Bali, Indonesia, on Wednesday.

item.title: Foreign Trade Competition Has Hurt Black and Disadvantaged Workers Most, Report Says
item.description: A government trade agency report suggested that the impact of trade policy differed for workers depending on their race and socioeconomic status.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: Offshoring to countries like China has led to economic disruptions in the United States that have had more dramatic effects on people of color, the report said.

item.title: Missile Fragment Brings Terror and Death to Kyiv Apartment Building
item.description: Residents told of a frantic escape: “We were just running around, no idea what to do,” one said.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Petro Romanchuk, 72, lives with his wife, Svitlana Romanchuk, 66, in a Kyiv apartment building that was struck by debris from a Russian missile shot down by Ukrainian air defense systems on Tuesday.

item.title: UK Pledges $1.19 Billion to Fight Diseases in Poor Countries
item.description: The contribution to the Global Fund is less than aid organizations had hoped for. Britain has been cutting foreign aid since 2020.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: A tuberculosis screening in Gugulethu township near Cape Town, South Africa.

item.title: In Colombia, Drilling Pays the Bills. The Country’s Leaders Want to Quit Oil.
item.description: The president says oil is his economy’s worst addiction. Phasing it out would be a global first for a major oil producer.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak and Federico Rios
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times

item.title: World Population Reaches 8 Billion, UN Says
item.description: The rapid population growth has been driven by the world’s poorest countries. More global challenges are ahead.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Commuters in Shanghai in September. The growth rate of China’s population is slowing.

item.title: Reopened Rail Route in Ukraine Restores Some Order
item.description: On Monday night, the first train from Kyiv departed for the Black Sea city, which had been pummeled for months by Russian attacks.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The first train to Mykolaiv from Kyiv since the Russian occupation of southern Ukraine at the beginning of the full-scale invasion in February preparing to depart on Monday.

item.title: Xi Addresses China-Australia Relationship With Prime Minister Albanese
item.description: The meeting between the leaders of China and Australia during the Group of 20 summit was another sign that Beijing is looking more broadly to ease diplomatic rifts with Western countries.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese of Australia called his meeting at the G20 summit with President Xi Jinping of China an “important step toward the stabilization” of their relationship but said differences remained.

item.title: Trump’s Precarious Moment
item.description: He’s expected to announce his third White House run at a time when he is politically vulnerable.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald Trump at a Miami rally last week.

item.title: Ukraine’s 15,000-Mile Lifeline
item.description: How the country’s vast rail system has helped it withstand an invasion.
item.dc:creator: Sarah A. Topol
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damaged railway lines near Zolochiv.

item.title: Is Rock Climbing the Future of Tourism in Malawi?
item.description: The small country in southeastern Africa is leveraging its little-known rock cliffs and boulders to develop local interest in climbing — and to draw adventure tourists.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levy

item.title: G20 Leaders Meet in Bali as Global Economy Faces Multiple Threats
item.description: High inflation, food insecurity and a possible global recession loom large as the Group of 20 summit discussions begin.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley and Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: President Biden in Bali on Monday. He and his counterparts in the Group of 20 are hoping to negotiate agreements this week to lower global oil prices and increase food supplies to poorer nations.

item.title: Novak Djokovic Is Cleared to Play in Australian Open
item.description: Australia has lifted the tennis star’s three-year ban on entering the country, imposed when he was deported in January over his failure to be vaccinated against Covid.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave and Matthew Futterman
item.media:description: Novak Djokovic during his opening match at the ATP Finals in Turin on Monday.

item.title: Bringing Sexy Back — To Fight H.I.V.
item.description: Most safer sex campaigns focus on danger and disease. Acknowledging the importance of pleasure — and how to make safe sex good sex — could make them more effective.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen

item.title: Beijing Signals Optimism for U.S. Ties After Biden-Xi Meeting
item.description: An upbeat photo in China’s main newspaper and comments by the foreign minister suggested that Beijing believes its relationship with Washington could improve.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: Pool photo by David Dee Delgado
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Wang Yi of China at the U.N. General Assembly gathering in September.

item.title: What Is the G20?
item.description: The Group of 20 nations aims to unite world leaders around shared challenges. Here is a look at what it is and what it does.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: The G20 space in Rome last year.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Dozens of young people have died in a lethal crackdown by the authorities in Iran.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: For Western Weapons, the Ukraine War Is a Beta Test
item.description: Though the battle for Ukraine remains largely a grinding artillery war, new advances in technology and training there are being closely monitored for the ways they are starting to shape combat.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers with Ukraine’s Carpathian Sich Battalion reviewing drone footage below the front line in May.

item.title: G20 Leaders Urge an End to the Russia-Ukraine War
item.description: World leaders gathering in Indonesia said their nations faced challenges from conflict and economic headwinds.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee, Muktita Suhartono, Carly Olson and Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, arriving at Ngurah Rai International Airport on the Indonesian island of Bali on Sunday.

item.title: Hun Sen of Cambodia Cuts G20 Trip Short After Testing Positive for Coronavirus
item.description: The prime minister has met with more than a dozen world leaders in recent days, including President Biden, who tested negative on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: President Biden with Prime Minister Hun Sen in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, on Saturday. The White House said Mr. Biden tested negative for the coronavirus on Tuesday morning.

item.title: Accounts of Torture Emerge From Kherson, Ukraine’s ‘City of Fear’
item.description: Just days after the southern city of Kherson was liberated after eight months of Russian occupation, accounts of beatings, torture and disappearances are emerging.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Andrew E. Kramer
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vyacheslav Lukashuk in Kherson on Monday. He said Russian soldiers had beaten him with rifle butts and had tried to suffocate him with a plastic bag for his pro-Ukrainian graffiti.

item.title: U.S. Investigating Killing of Shireen Abu Akleh in West Bank, Israel Says
item.description: The Justice Department inquiry is a shift by the Biden administration, which had said that Shireen Abu Akleh was probably killed accidentally, by gunfire from the position of Israeli soldiers.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial for the journalist Shireen Abu Akleh at the Jenin refugee camp in the West Bank in May.

item.title: C.I.A. Director Warns Russian Counterpart Against Using Nuclear Weapons
item.description: William Burns’s talks with Russia’s foreign intelligence chief are the most senior in-person meetings since the start of the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Jim Tankersley and Edward Wong
item.media:description: William J. Burns, the C.I.A. director, held a face-to-face meeting with his Russian counterpart after a period of rising tensions over nuclear issues.

item.title: With Tensions Mounting, Biden and Xi Try a Warmer Tone
item.description: The American and Chinese leaders invoked years of personal contact as they met before the G20, seeking to pull back from outright conflict on a host of issues.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, left, China’s top leader, and President Biden met in Bali, Indonesia, on Monday.

item.title: German Government Nationalizes Gas Unit Seized From Gazprom
item.description: The former Gazprom Germania, a subsidiary of the Russian state-owned gas monopoly, is deemed essential to Germany’s energy security.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: Part of the gas storage facility at Rehden, Germany. The facility, once owned by a unit of Gazprom, has been nationalized by the German government.

item.title: Blinken to Visit China in 2023 After Biden and Xi’s Meeting
item.description: The trip is aimed at keeping the lines of communication open and having frank exchanges about important issues at senior levels in order to avoid conflict.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: President Biden meeting with China’s leader, Xi Jinping, on Monday in Bali, Indonesia.

item.title: Brazil, Indonesia and Congo Sign Rainforest Protection Pact
item.description: The three countries, home to more than half of the world’s tropical rainforests, have agreed to negotiate a “funding mechanism” for conservation.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak and Manuela Andreoni
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rainforests were burned to clear land for a cattle ranch in Mato Grosso state, Brazil. Brazil’s president-elect, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, who will address the United Nations climate summit on Wednesday, has promised to end deforestation in the Amazon.

item.title: As the Pandemic Drags On, Americans Struggle for New Balance
item.description: As offices, restaurants and schools fill up, people are adjusting expectations and habits in another moment of deep uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:description: A sign implored visitors to the Oculus in Manhattan in May to wear masks. They are no longer required in public places, even as some experts fear new variants and waning immunity may lead to a surge this winter.

item.title: At the summit, Biden’s advisers provide clues about U.S. strategy on China.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: President Biden’s team at the meeting with Xi Jinping, China’s leader.

item.title: Alaa Abd El Fattah Is Alive, His Family Says
item.description: A note in the handwriting of Alaa Abd El Fattah, who has been on hunger strike for about seven months, read: “I began drinking water, my vitals are good.”
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Alaa Abd El Fattah at a court in Cairo in 2015. His hunger strike has cast a shadow on the United Nations climate summit in Egypt.

item.title: CIA Director Warns Russia Against Use of Nuclear Weapons in Ukraine
item.description: The National Security Council said William J. Burns’s meeting was not in any way to negotiate or to discuss any settlement of the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley and Edward Wong
item.media:description: William J. Burns, the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, in July.

item.title: Turkey Accuses U.S. of Complicity in Istanbul Attack
item.description: Turkish police arrested a female suspect and accused her of entering from Syria to carry out the bombing on Kurdish orders. The U.S. is allied with a Kurdish-led militia in Syria.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Visitors laid red flowers at a memorial on Monday at the site of Sunday’s attack in Istanbul.
